title: Rich in Sydney: how much you need to own to be considered wealthy
text:
Ever wondered what it would take to be considered “rich” in Sydney?

There is some debate over how much one would need to earn to be considered wealthy in monetary terms, but on the property front it is a lot clearer.

Analysis of CoreLogic data revealed a homeowner would need to have a house with a minimum value of $3.21 million to be among the wealthiest property owners.

Houses priced at this level or higher were within the top two per cent of the market, according to CoreLogic head of research Tim Lawless.

MORE: Aussie record smashed with $140m sale

‘James Bond house’ so hot right now

Apartment owners with properties valued at $1.88 million or more made up the top two per cent of unit owners, he said.

But there was some variance in what it took for a property to be considered pricey in different Sydney regions.

Properties within exclusive eastern suburbs enclave Woollahra were only within the 98th percentile once the price went above $8.16 million.

In lower north shore suburb Mosman the threshold was $7.79 million and in nearby North Sydney council it was $6.04 million.

Houses were at the top of the Blacktown market if they were priced above $1.04 million.

Mr Lawless also revealed in CoreLogic’s weekly Property Pulse newsletter that Sydney’s priciest homes were much more valuable than those in other states.

“Nationally, you’ve made it into the 98th percentile if you own a house worth at least $2.16 million,” he said, adding apartments worth $1.43 million or more were within the 98th percentile for units.

MORE: Worst suburbs for parking revealed



Unexpected downside of short-stay homes

The top of the house market in Melbourne was $2.53 million, nearly $800,000 lower than in Sydney.

Adelaide’s priciest houses were valued at $1.17 million, which is only marginally higher than the middle of the market in Sydney.

Houses at the 98 percentile in Brisbane were valued at about $1.29 million or more.

In regional South Australia, the top two per cent of the market was only $553,790.
description: To be considered rich in Sydney, you’d need to hold a certain level of real estate assets, according to new research which revealed how homeowners measure up across the city.
